clinical_study.brief_title: Stand if You Can: A Standing Intervention in Long Term Care
clinical_study.official_title: Stand if You Can- A Randomized Control Trial

brief_summary.textblock: It is currently unknown if reducing sitting time, an activity that is highly prevalent in frail older adults living in long term care (LTC) facilities, is associated with an improvement in physical capacity such as walking speed. Simple tasks such as walking speed is associated with important outcomes for residents in LTC such as autonomy and hospitalization. The investigators hypothesize that standing an additional 100 minutes per week for 5 months will result in a clinically meaningful improvement in walking speed (0.1m/sec) in LTC residents compared to residents receiving a sitting social activity.

detailed_description.textblock: LTC facilities from Moncton and Fredericton will be recruited, with half of the LTC facilities randomized as the intervention and half as the control group. The investigators are aiming to enrol half of the LTC in Fredericton and half in Moncton. A total of 88 residents (44 in the control group, 44 in the intervention group) will be enrolled in the program.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Long term care (LTC) facilities will be recruited, with half of the LTC facilities randomized as the intervention (n=2) and half as the control group (n=2).
study_design_info.masking_description: Investigator was masked at pre-testing. It was unknown which participants would be receiving the intervention. However, due to resources this was not repeated at post testing

primary_outcome.time_frame: Pre and post, following the 5-month intervention
primary_outcome.description: Measured by the 10m walking speed test

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Pre and post testing (following the 5 month intervention)
secondary_outcome.description: Measured by a portable device, which has sensors that detects sway at the feet (shifting pressure)
The Geriatric Anxiety Inventory (Scale 0-1. Higher score more desirable.)
Semi-structured interviews with residents (participants and non-participants), family members and staff will be administered at the end of the study

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in lipid levels in an individual's capillary blood. Blood received via a finger prick and analyzed with a cardiochek device
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Pre-Post Testing (before and following the month intervention)
secondary_outcome.description: Capillary blood analyzed with a cardiochek device.
Mini Mental State Examination Questionnaire (Subscores: 0-1, 0-2, 0-3, 0-5. Summed to receive total score. 0-24 and above. Higher score is more desirable.)
DeJong Gierveld Loneliness Scale (0 to 6 point scale- Closer to 0 is desirable), UCLA Loneliness Scale (1-4 scale. Reversed scoring on half of the questions)
Falls Efficacy Scale-International (1-4 scale. Lower score more desirable.)
Geriatric Depression Scale Short Form (0-1 scale. Lower score is desirable.)
Using hand-held dynamometer to quantify leg strength through knee extension
Using the 30second sit-stand test following senior fitness test protocol

secondary_outcome.time_frame: The number of falls will be collected from three timeframes: 1. Between 6 months prior to and the start of program 2. the duration of the program (5 months) 3. From the end of the program to 6 months follow up
secondary_outcome.description: Falls, injuries due to falls and hospitalization will be collected at 3 timepoints

arm_group.description: Participants be exposed to an additional 100 minutes of standing per week. Participants will do this by standing for 20 minutes Monday through Friday.
Control group will receive social visits, but no exposure to standing

intervention.description: Standing for an additional 100 minutes per week; 20 minutes Monday-Friday
